course.title: Default - IBM MQ Operations and Administration for Distributed Environments
course.prerequisites: Completion of the Interskill IBM MQ Operations and Administration course or equivalent practical knowledge of IBM MQ fundamentals.

modules.title: General Administration
modules.description: This module covers the installation, configuration, and basic administration of IBM MQ in distributed environments, focusing on command-line tools and configuration files.

sections.title: Installing IBM MQ
sections.overview: IBM MQ is installed using package managers like rpm (Linux) or MSI (Windows).
key_steps: Download and install the MQ package (e.g., rpm -ivh MQSeries*.rpm).
Run setmqinst to set the primary installation.

sections.title: Creating and Starting Queue Managers
commands: crtmqm QM1 to create a queue manager.
endmqm QM1 to stop it (quiesced mode).

sections.title: MQSC Commands
sections.overview: Run MQSC commands using runmqsc QM1 for queue manager administration.

qm_ini.description: Queue manager configuration file (qm.ini) for settings like logging.

sections.title: MQ Explorer
sections.description: GUI tool for managing MQ objects, available on Windows and Linux.
sections.access: Launch via desktop shortcut or mqexplorer command.

knowledge_check.question: What command installs IBM MQ on a Linux system?
What command verifies the MQ installation version?
Which command creates a queue manager named QM1?
How do you start a queue manager named QM1?
What is the purpose of the endmqm command?
What command runs MQSC commands for queue manager QM1?
How do you define a local queue named MY.QUEUE in MQSC?
What is the purpose of the qm.ini file?
What setting in qm.ini controls log file size?
What file configures client channel connections?
What is the default port for MQ listener in distributed environments?
What command displays queue manager status?
How do you access MQ Explorer?
options: B: mqexplorer command or desktop shortcut

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of the -u option in crtmqm?
What command stops a queue manager in quiesced mode?
What is the role of setmqinst?
How do you define a listener in MQSC?
What is the purpose of the SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE?
What command checks queue depth in MQSC?
What is a key difference between MQ on distributed systems and z/OS?
options: A: Distributed uses JCL for queue manager startup
B: Distributed uses file-based logs, z/OS uses VSAM
D: Distributed uses SMP/E for installation
E: Distributed lacks MQ Explorer support

modules.title: Architecture, MQ IPT, Firewall, Gateway QMgrs
modules.description: This module covers IBM MQ architecture in distributed environments, including MQ Internet Pass-Thru (IPT), firewall considerations, and Gateway Queue Managers for routing.

sections.title: MQ Architecture Overview
sections.overview: MQ uses a hub-and-spoke or clustered architecture with queue managers, channels, and queues.
components: Queue Managers: Manage queues and messages.
Channels: Connect queue managers for message transfer.
Clusters: Group queue managers for load balancing.

sections.title: MQ Internet Pass-Thru (IPT)
sections.description: MQ IPT enables secure message transfer over the internet without VPNs.
sections.configuration: Configure IPT server with mqs_ipt.ini and run mqs_ipt.

sections.title: Firewall Considerations
requirements: Open TCP port 1414 (or custom) for MQ channels.
Allow MQ IPT ports (e.g., 1415) for internet traffic.
Use NAT or proxies for secure external access.

sections.title: Gateway Queue Managers
sections.description: Gateway QMgrs route messages between internal and external systems.
sections.setup: Define sender/receiver channels and alias queues.

sections.title: MQ Clusters
sections.description: Clusters simplify administration by sharing queue definitions.

knowledge_check.question: What is a key component of MQ architecture?
What is the role of channels in MQ architecture?
What does MQ Internet Pass-Thru (IPT) enable?
options: B: Secure message transfer over the internet

knowledge_check.question: What file configures MQ IPT settings?
What command starts the MQ IPT server?
What is the default MQ port that must be open in a firewall?
What firewall configuration supports MQ IPT?
options: B: Open port 1415 for IPT traffic

knowledge_check.question: What is the role of a Gateway Queue Manager?
How do you define a sender channel for a Gateway QMgr?
What is a benefit of using MQ clusters?
What MQSC command defines a cluster queue?
How do you designate a queue manager as a cluster repository?
What is a key firewall consideration for MQ channels?
options: B: Use UDP for message transfer

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of an alias queue in a Gateway QMgr?
options: B: Routes messages to target queues

knowledge_check.question: What command displays cluster queue status?
What does MQ IPT eliminate the need for?
options: B: VPNs for secure internet transfer

knowledge_check.question: How do you define a receiver channel for a Gateway QMgr?
What is a key difference between MQ clusters and Gateway QMgrs?
options: A: Clusters use VSAM, Gateway QMgrs use files
B: Clusters share queues, Gateway QMgrs route messages
C: Clusters require IPT, Gateway QMgrs use VPNs
D: Clusters use JCL, Gateway QMgrs use MQSC
E: Clusters disable channels, Gateway QMgrs enable them

knowledge_check.question: What port is commonly used for MQ IPT traffic?
What is a benefit of Gateway QMgrs in a distributed environment?
options: B: Isolates internal and external messaging

modules.title: Security, SSL/TLS, and Miscellaneous Objects
modules.description: This module covers securing IBM MQ in distributed environments, including SSL/TLS configuration, user authentication, and managing miscellaneous objects like topics and subscriptions.

sections.title: User Authentication
sections.description: Use OS user accounts or MQ authentication (e.g., CHCKCLNT).
sections.example: ALTER QMGR CHCKCLNT(REQUIRED) to enforce client authentication.

sections.title: SSL/TLS Configuration
sections.description: Secure channels using SSL/TLS with certificates stored in a keystore.

sections.title: Channel Authentication Records (CHLAUTH)
sections.description: Control channel access using CHLAUTH rules.

sections.title: Topics and Subscriptions
sections.description: Manage publish/subscribe messaging with topics and subscriptions.

sections.title: Advanced Message Security (AMS)
sections.description: Encrypts message content at the queue level.

knowledge_check.question: What MQSC command enforces client authentication?
What command manages SSL certificates in MQ?
What is the purpose of a keystore in MQ?
What MQSC command secures a sender channel with SSL?
What does CHLAUTH do in MQ security?
How do you block all access to a channel using CHLAUTH?
options: A: SET CHLAUTH(MYCHAN) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) ADDRESS('*') USERSRC(NOACCESS)

knowledge_check.question: What is the purpose of Advanced Message Security (AMS)?
options: B: Encrypts message content in queues

knowledge_check.question: How do you define a topic in MQSC?
What MQSC command creates a subscription?
What is a cipher suite in SSL/TLS configuration?
What command displays channel authentication rules?
How do you enable AMS for a queue?
What does the CHCKCLNT(REQUIRED) setting do?
What is a topic string used for?
What command checks subscription status?
What is the default location for the keystore file?
What does the SSLCIPH parameter specify?
How do you restrict channel access to a specific IP?
options: A: SET CHLAUTH(MYCHAN) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) ADDRESS('192.168.1.1') USERSRC(CHANNEL)

knowledge_check.question: What is a benefit of using topics in MQ?
What tool is used to create an SSL certificate for MQ?

modules.title: Development and Programming
modules.description: This module covers developing applications for IBM MQ in distributed environments, including APIs, message formats, and programming best practices.

sections.title: MQ APIs
sections.description: Use MQI, JMS, or REST APIs for MQ interactions.

sections.title: Message Formats
sections.description: Messages can be text, binary, or structured (e.g., JSON, XML).
properties: RFH2: Rules and Formatting Header for advanced messaging.

sections.title: Client Connections
sections.description: Connect applications to MQ using client channels.
sections.example: MQCONNX with MQCNO for client connection options.

sections.title: Publish/Subscribe Programming
sections.description: Use JMS or MQI for pub/sub messaging with topics.
sections.example: MQSUB to subscribe to a topic.

knowledge_check.question: What is the primary API for MQ programming in C?
What MQI call connects to a queue manager?
What is the purpose of the MQMD structure?
What does the RFH2 header support?
What MQI call puts a message on a queue?
What is used for pub/sub messaging in MQ?
What MQI call subscribes to a topic?
What JMS component sends messages to a queue?
What is a best practice for MQ programming?
options: D: Set all messages to non-persistent

knowledge_check.question: What MQI call opens a queue?
What does MQCONNX provide over MQCONN?
What message property controls persistence?
What is a common message format for MQ applications?
What does the JMS QueueConnectionFactory do?
What is a common MQRC error code for connection failure?
What API supports REST-based MQ interactions?

What does the MQMD.MessageId field do?
What is a key consideration for client connections?

modules.title: MQ Troubleshooting
modules.description: This module covers diagnosing and resolving common IBM MQ issues in distributed environments, including log analysis, error codes, and channel issues.

sections.title: Common Error Codes
sections.description: Key MQRC codes include 2058 (QMgr not available), 2085 (unknown object).
sections.example: Check logs for MQRC 2058 and verify QMgr status with dspmq.

sections.title: Log Analysis
sections.description: Errors logged in /var/mqm/errors and /var/mqm/qmgrs/QM1/errors.

sections.title: Channel Issues
sections.description: Diagnose channel failures (e.g., AMQ9504 for connection refused).

sections.title: Queue Issues
sections.description: Check for inhibited queues or full queues.

sections.title: Tracing
sections.description: Enable tracing with strmqtrc and format with dspmqtrc.

knowledge_check.question: What does MQRC 2058 indicate?
Where are queue manager errors logged?
What command checks channel status?
What does MQRC 2085 indicate?
What command pings a channel to test connectivity?
What is a common cause of AMQ9504 channel errors?
How do you check if a queue is inhibited?
What command enables MQ tracing?
What command formats MQ trace files?
What does a full queue cause in MQ?
Where are global MQ errors logged?
What command resolves a queue full issue?
What is a common fix for MQRC 2058?
options: B: Verify queue manager is running

knowledge_check.question: What does DISPLAY QUEUE(MY.QUEUE) CURDEPTH show?
options: B: Current number of messages in queue

knowledge_check.question: What is a symptom of a channel connection failure?
What should you check for an SSL-related channel error?
What does MQRC 2033 indicate?
How do you verify a queue manager is running?
What is a common cause of inhibited queues?
What tool helps analyze MQ trace files?

modules.title: Alerts and Metric Collection
modules.description: This module covers configuring alerts and collecting performance metrics in IBM MQ distributed environments, using tools like MQ events and external monitoring systems.

sections.title: MQ Event Messages
sections.description: Enable queue manager and channel event messages for monitoring.

sections.title: Performance Metrics
sections.description: Collect metrics using DISPLAY commands or external tools like Tivoli.

sections.title: Monitoring Tools
tools: Prometheus with MQ Exporter: Open-source metric collection.

sections.title: Alert Configuration
sections.description: Configure queue depth alerts or channel status alerts.

sections.title: Log and Event Analysis
sections.description: Analyze AMQERR logs and event queues for issues.

options: B: Enables queue depth high alerts

hands_on_labs: Install IBM MQ on a Linux system and create a queue manager.
Configure a sender/receiver channel pair with SSL/TLS.
Set up a Gateway Queue Manager and test message routing.
Create a topic and subscription for pub/sub messaging.
Enable queue depth alerts and monitor using MQ Explorer.
resources: Sample MQSC scripts and configuration files provided in course materials.
additional_notes.environment: Access to a Linux or Windows system with IBM MQ installed for labs.
